c74object.name: irmeasure~
c74object.digest: Measure IRs of single or multichannel systems using a range of excitation signals
c74object.description: The irmeasure~ object can be used to measure IRs using the ESS (exponentially swept sine), MLS (maximum length sequences) or various coloured-noise signals (which whilst less accurate, may be preferable in occupied rooms where a rough estimate is acceptable).

inlet.description: The number of audio signal inputs for realtime processing is determined by the argument(s) to the object (up to 128)

outlet.description: The number of audio signal outputs for realtime processing is determined by the argument(s) to the object (up to 128)
Penultimate (right) outlet: Measurement Progress (0..1 or ms depending on the absprogress attribute)
Final (rightmost) outlet: bang on completion of called process

method.name: activeins
method.description: One can set the number of active measurement inputs and outputs, to enable more generalised patching.

method.name: activeouts
method.description: One can set the number of active measurement inputs and outputs, to enable more generalised patching.

method.name: brown
method.description:
Syntax: brown [<int: length>] [<int/float: fade_in>] [<int/float: fade_out>] [<int: ir_length>]
Note that noise signals will be identical each time when the same parameters are used.
brown defaults: 10000ms / 10ms / 10ms / 5000ms

method.name: clear
method.digest: Cancel measurements and clear all allocated memory

method.name: dump
method.digest: Place the internal processed ouput for one input channel into a named buffer~
method.description:
Syntax: dump [<int: in_chan>] <symbol: output_buffer_name>
!! The dump message can only be used AFTER processing irmeasure~ !!
The dump message allows the processsed recording (containing all IRs for a given input channel, including nonlinear components where relevant) for one of the measurement input channels to be dumped to a named buffer~.

method.name: extract
method.digest: Extract the internal recording for one input channel into a named buffer~
method.description:
Syntax: extract [<int: in_chan>] <symbol: output_buffer_name>
!! The extract message can only be used AFTER processing irmeasure~ !!
The extract message allows the recording (without processing) for one of the measurement input channels to be extracted to a named buffer~.

method.name: getir
method.description:
Syntax: getir [<int: in_chan>] <symbol: buffer_name> [<int: out_chan>] [<int: harmonic>]
!! IRs must be retrieved to a buffer~ with this message !!
getir defaults: 1 / [name] / 1 / 1. N.B. the harmonics arg (arg 3) must be an integer >= 1.

method.name: mls
method.digest: Make a Maximum Length Sequence recording
method.description:
Syntax: mls [<int: order>] [<int: ir_length>]
The MLS is an ordered noise-like signal containing all possible sequencs of -1 and 1 of a given length (according to the order). The overall length of the MLS is (2^N) -1 samples where N is the order.
mls defaults: 18 / 5000ms

method.name: pink
method.description:
Syntax: pink [<int: length>] [<int/float: fade_in>] [<int/float: fade_out>] [<int: ir_length>]
Note that noise signals will be identical each time when the same parameters are used.
pink defaults: 10000ms / 10ms / 10ms / 5000ms

method.name: reprocess
method.digest: Reprocess the recordings using different settings
method.description: Once the measurement is finished the recordings are automatically processed. The reprocess message allows one to reprocess the recordings using different deconvolution settings. See the deconv* attributes for details.

method.name: signal
method.description: The number of audio signal inputs is determined by the argument(s) to the object. Minimum = 1, maximum = 128.

method.name: sweep
method.description:
Syntax: sweep [<int/float: low_freq>] [<int/float: high_freq>] [<int: length>] [<int/float: fade_in>] [<int/float: fade_out>] [<int: ir_length>]
The ESS (exponentially swept sine) is a signal with good signal to noise and distortion rejection properties for IR measurement. The inverse signal can be convolved directly with the resultant recordings, without the need for deconvolution.
sweep defaults: 20Hz / nyquist / 30000ms / 50ms / 10ms / 5000ms

method.name: tone
method.description:
Syntax: tone <int/float: frequency> [<int: out_chan>]
tone defaults: frequency Hz / 0 (= all)

method.name: white
method.description:
Syntax: white [<int: length>] [<int/float: fade_in>] [<int/float: fade_out>] [<int: ir_length>]
Note that noise signals will be identical each time when the same parameters are used.
white defaults: 10000ms / 10ms / 10ms / 5000ms

attribute.name: absprogress
attribute.description: When the absprogress is on, the progress output is in milliseconds, otherwise the progress output is normalised 0..1.

attribute.name: amp
attribute.description: Sets the maximum ampltiude of the generated signal in dB.

attribute.name: ampcurve
attribute.description:
Instead of producing sweeps with a flat amplitude response the ampltiude can be varied with frequency, so as to best suit the measured system (for instance using lower ampltudes at low and high frequencies, thus avoiding distortion of the measurement speaker).
When blank, sweeps will be flat. Otherwise you should specify the ampitude response using frequency (Hz) & amplitude (dB) pairs.
Example: ampcurve 10 -20 40 0 16000 0 19000 -25

attribute.name: bandlimit
attribute.description:
When bandlimit is on, measurements taken using the sweep signal are automatically bandlimited to the range of the sweep (the deconvolution filter is automatically generated, bypassing the deconvolution filter settings).
The fade times determine the steepness of the filter slope at low and high frequencies (shorter fade in times give a steeper LF rolloff, shorter fade out times give a steeper HF rolloff). This is the most appropriate setting for acoustic measurements.
When off, the deconvolution filter settings are used for sweep measurements. This may be more appropriate for measuring within a digital system, or when hand tuning of settings is desirable.
This attribute does not affect measruements using the mls or coloured noise signals.

attribute.name: deconvdelay
attribute.description:
Deconvolution can result in time-aliasing. In order to make sure that the resultant IR is correctly contained within the period of the FFT, it may be necessary to introduce a modelling delay (shifting the output of the deconvolution).
This delay can either be set in milliseconds or using the symbol 'center' which sets the delay to half of the FFT size.
This attribute is not available in the irmeasure~ & irextract~ objects, as the timing is tightly controlled by the synchronous recording/playback process, making a modelling delay unnecessary.
units: milliseconds or symbol

attribute.name: deconvfilter
attribute.description:
Regardless of the deconvolution mode (deconvmode) it is necessary to set a specification for how to control the deconvolution over the frequency range. The deconvfilter specification sets a frequency curve to apply to the relevant mode.
You may either specify a static value in dB, or a list of freq/dB values to vary the specification with frequency. For regularisation this sets the constant value to add to the divisor.
For clipping it sets the minimum values allowed for the division. For filter it sets the shape of the filter.
Typically, for standard usage, very low or high frequencies are liable to blowup through overcorrection or numeric error. Thus higher values for regularisation and clipping are appropraite at low/high frequencies.
The filter mode works in the inverse, and lower values (less gain) are generally more appropriate for extremes of frequency.
Additionally you may specify the name of a buffer~ as the filter specification in which case the power spectrum of the buffer~ is used to determine the specification for regularisation and clipping modes,
and the buffer~ is applied directly as a convolution filter in filter mode (ignoring the deconvphase attribute setting in this case).
This allows a high degree of control of the process for special applications or custom solutions.
units: symbol & list

attribute.name: deconvmode
attribute.description:
Deconvolution must be controlled so as to prevent filter blow-up or excessive time-aliasing. The control is equivalent to filtering the result of a staightforward complex division in the frequency domain (hence the term filter). The three modes are:
0, Regularisation: Regularise the division by adding a constant to the division
1, Clipping: Clip the denominator in the division
2, Specify the filter explicitly
units: int, default: 0, range: 0..2

attribute.name: deconvphase
attribute.description:
The method by which deconvolution is controlled acts as a FIR filter on result of the 'true deconvolution'. This filter will produce time smearing of the result. This can result in pre or post ring in the resultant IR.
By controlling the phase of the implicit filter we can control this ring.
The default is minimum phase which post-rings only. The phase may either be specified as a float value between 0 and 1 (where 0 is minimum phase, 0.5 is linear phase and 1 is maximum phase),
or using any of the following symbols:
min / minimum: Minimum Phase
lin / linear: Linear Phase
max / maximum: Maximum Phase
units: float or symbol, default: 0 / minimum, range: 0..1 or min/lin/max

attribute.name: deconvrange
attribute.description:
When deconvmode is clipping the denominator of the divsion can be clipped to both minimum values (controlling peaks in the output) and also maximum values (controlling dips in the output).
The deconvrange attibute sets the maximum values in relation to the filter specification. Similarly to the deconvolution filter specification (deconvfilter), you may either specify a single value in dB or use a list of freq/dB pairs to vary the range with frequency.
units: symbol & list

attribute.name: invamp
attribute.description:
When invamp is on, irextract~ will perform deconvolution taking into account the output level. This correctly measures the gain of the system tested.
As for acoustic measurements the exact gain of the analog part of the system is essentially arbitrary (due to mic gains etc) so invamp defaults to off.
When measuring digital systems etc, or situations where the gain is controlled, invamp should be switched on to correctly capture gain information.

attribute.name: irgain
attribute.description:
An arbitrary gain factor in dB can be applied to any recording.
This is so that in a situation where a plain recording may produce very high or very low overall gains, one can mitigate this for quick testing purposes.
units: dB, float, default: 0

attribute.name: resize
attribute.description:
If on, the buffer~ will resize to the necessary size before write. Resizing erases all contents of the buffer~.
Otherwise, output will ONLY happen if there is enough room to write the entire output, leaving the latter contents of the buffer~ and other buffer~ channels unaffected.
units: flag, default: 1, range: 0/1

attribute.name: writechan
attribute.description:
Sets the channel number for buffer~ writing (1-4). If the specified channel does not exist the value is wrapped within the existing number of channels (so 3 will write to channel 1 of a two-channel buffer~, 4 to channel 2).
units: int, default: 1, range: 1..4

c74object.discussion:
As well as handling multichannel situations, the object also deals with the processing and chopping of IRs (including the relative timing of non-linear components when using the ESS signal), allowing the user to retrieve the IRs directly without needing to carry out recording, deconvolution and chopping processes manually.
In use, an excitation signal is sent to the measurement outputs of the object, (which are routed to the input of a system - e.g. a speaker in a room) whilst the object simultaneously records the output of the same system (captured for instance by a mic in a room) - thus it is necessary to create a loop through the sytem from output to input.
Further Reading:
ESS Measurement:
A. Farina, “Simultaneous measurement of impulse response and distortion with a swept-sine technique,” in Audio Engineering Society Convention 108, 2 2000
A. Farina, “Advancements in impulse response measure- ments by sine sweeps,” in Audio Engineering Society Convention 122, 5 2007
A. Nova ́k and, L. Simon, F. Kadlec, and P. Lotton, “Nonlinear system identification using exponential swept-sine signal,” Instrumentation and Measure- ment, IEEE Transactions on, vol. 59, no. 8, pp. 2220 –2229, Aug. 2010
MLS Measurement:
D. D. Rife and J. Vanderkooy, “Transfer-function measurement with maximum-length sequences,” J. Audio Eng. Soc, vol. 37, no. 6, pp. 419–444, 1989
Comparisions:
G.-B. Stan, J.-J. Embrechts, and D. Archambeau, “Comparison of different impulse response mea- surement techniques,” J. Audio Eng. Soc, vol. 50, no. 4, pp. 249–262, 2002
